image.altText: Two people wearing hard hats looking out over a gold mine pit.

title.children: 'Huge concern' as worker is diagnosed with incurable lung disease at Australia's biggest gold mine

image.altText: group of indigenous men standing

items.synopsis: Since 2000, the rate of Indigenous Australians imprisoned has risen eight times that of non-Indigenous Australians. There are hopes a Voice to Parliament will help reverse that trend.

title.children: Australia has one of the highest Indigenous incarceration rates in the world. Could a Voice to Parliament change that?

image.altText: A roll cloud over the ocean

items.synopsis: Thunderstorms and heavy rain are forecast for parts of Victoria and New South Wales, dousing fires but bringing the threat of flash flooding, as a low pressure system intensifies over the eastern states.

title.children: Dangerous wind, heavy rain, flooding forecast to hit eastern states as intense storm system deepens

image.altText: A woman stands while holding a copy of a report in her hands.

image.altText: A woman looks directly at camera.

title.children: Sarah does 90 per cent of her grocery shopping online — but she's not checking out at the big supermarkets

title.children: Homes lost as fires threaten NSW coast while inland residents face flood risk

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in Voice referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned earlier, the prime minister says more than 600,000 Australians have voted early. Early referendum voting opened across the country this week. You can find an early polling location near you using the AEC's 'Where Can I Vote?' tool. Below are the reasons why you can vote early in the Voice referendum: You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote You are more than 8km from a polling place You are travelling You can't leave your workplace to vote You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is) You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained You are a silent elector You have a reasonable fear for your safety
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How to vote early in the Voice referendum

props.alt: Five people have their heads down and backs towards the camera looking at a piece of paper.

children.content: Early voting has kicked off around the country.
(ABC Gippsland: Kerrin Thomas)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Postal vote applications for the Voice referendum close on October 11. Here are several reasons why you can apply for a single event postal vote if you can't get to a polling place on voting day: You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote You are more than 8km from a polling place You are travelling You can't leave your workplace to vote You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is) You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained You are a silent elector You have a reasonable fear for your safety You can read more on whether you are eligible to apply for a postal vote here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Applying for a postal vote

featuredLink.title: Voice to Parliament referendum postal vote applications are open

children.content: Postal vote applications for the Voice referendum close on
October 11
Here are several reasons why you can apply for
a single event postal vote
if you can't get to a polling place on voting day:
You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote
You are more than 8km from a polling place
You are travelling
You can't leave your workplace to vote
You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is)
You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital
You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place
You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained
You are a silent elector
You have a reasonable fear for your safety
You can read more on whether you are eligible to apply for a postal vote here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in the referendum. "I take great heart in that, that Australians are eager to vote 'Yes' in this referendum because they know what it's about is just two things: recognition of First Nations people in our nation's founding document and secondly about a non-binding advisory committee," he said. "That's all this is. [It's] to give advice on matters affecting Indigenous Australians, because if you do that, if you listen to people, you get better outcomes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says more than 600,000 Australians have voted

title.children: Stronger-than-expected US jobs data stokes 'higher for longer' interest rate fears, ASX follows Wall Street lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With petrol prices sticking well above $2 a litre in capital cities, the federal government is facing renewed pressure to step in and provide some relief for motorists by reinstating the fuel excise discount. The fuel excise is the tax on petrol and diesel that's levied by the federal government. It was cut by 22 cents a litre last year, but the Albanese government allowed it to expire. Yesterday the PM was asked if he'd consider cutting the excise again, to which Anthony Albanese said he doesn't make tax policy on the run. But energy economist at the Commonwealth Bank, Vivek Dhar says it isn't the tax that's keeping the prices high — it's all got to do with oil prices. "We have seen OPEC+, which is a group of countries that control about 40 per cent of global supply, effectively reduce production which has led to this higher oil price environment ," he said. "So that's been really the key driver of higher petrol prices, but what's made this situation worse has been the weakening in the Australian dollar ." For those who are hoping for relief at the bowser, Mr Dhar says we can expect to be waiting a while. "There has been an interesting drop in oil prices over the last in 2-3 trading sessions, that's been a 5% fall, so that will give some reprieve," he said. "But our concern is any fall in oil prices will be almost mitigated by falls in the Australian dollar. "We may be stuck in this petrol price environment of 2.10 to 2.20 a litre for the foreseeable future ... we're thinking [falls are] more a story for early 2024." — Reporting by political reporter Evelyn Manfield
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government showing no signs of reinstating fuel excise discount

It was

, but the Albanese government allowed it to expire.
Yesterday the PM was asked if he'd consider cutting the excise again, to which Anthony Albanese said he doesn't make tax policy on the run.
But energy economist at the Commonwealth Bank,
Vivek Dhar
says it isn't the tax that's keeping the prices high — it's all got to do with
oil prices
"We have seen OPEC+, which is a group of countries that control about 40 per cent of global supply,
effectively reduce production which has led to this higher oil price environment
," he said.
"So that's been really the key driver of higher petrol prices, but
what's made this situation worse has been the weakening in the Australian dollar
For those who are hoping for relief at the bowser, Mr Dhar says we can expect to be waiting a while.
"There has been an interesting drop in oil prices over the last in 2-3 trading sessions, that's been a 5% fall, so that will give some reprieve," he said.
"But our concern is
any fall in oil prices will be almost mitigated by falls in the Australian dollar
"We may be
stuck in this petrol price environment of 2.10 to 2.20 a litre for the foreseeable future
... we're thinking [falls are] more a story for early 2024."
— Reporting by political reporter Evelyn Manfield

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jean Bell Victorian residential builder Chatham Homes has entered voluntary liquidation, owing 200 creditors about $2 million. Chatham Homes has about 50 unfinished projects across Melbourne, Ballarat and Torquay. On Monday, owner Bradley Hall made the call to voluntarily liquidate the company and let go of 16 staff, citing challenging economic conditions. AS Advisory liquidator Andrew Schwartz says initial investigations show the business owes $2 million to 200 creditors, who are mostly tradespeople. Mr Schwartz says letters have been sent to clients and alternative builders are being contacted to complete unfinished builds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victorian-based builder Chatham Homes enters voluntary liquidation

children.content: Reporting by Jean Bell
Victorian residential builder Chatham Homes has entered voluntary liquidation, owing 200 creditors about $2 million.
Chatham Homes has about 50 unfinished projects across Melbourne, Ballarat and Torquay.
On Monday, owner Bradley Hall made the call to voluntarily liquidate the company and let go of 16 staff, citing challenging economic conditions.
AS Advisory liquidator Andrew Schwartz says initial investigations show the business owes $2 million to 200 creditors, who are mostly tradespeople.
Mr Schwartz says letters have been sent to clients and alternative builders are being contacted to complete unfinished builds.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, the Australian sharemarket has opened lower this morning, down 0.5% to 6,908 points as of 10:30am AEDT. (For live figures at any time, head to the top of the blog.) In very early trade, the ASX hit a six-month low, down 0.6%, but has picked up slightly since. It follows the sharp selling on Wall Street overnight, off the back of that US jobs data stoking concerns that interest rates are going to stay elevated for longer than investors had anticipated. All of the sectors are firmly in the red, with the exception of utilities, which has gained 0.6%. Academic and educational services has shed the most at -1.5%, followed by industrials (-1.1%), technology (-1%) and real estate (-0.8%). The top movers so far: Ramelius Resources +2.9% IPH +2.8% Bega Cheese +1.6% Northern Star Resources +1.5% Capricorn Metals +1.5% And the bottom movers so far: Coronado Global Resources -4.5% Nanosonics -2.9% News Corp -2.7% Weebit Nano -2.6% Virgin Money UK -2.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX falls to six-month low at the open on US interest rate worries
